captions.text:
2017 will be remembered by gaming historians
as the year of the premature ejaculation.

We had some lovely tumbles in the first two
quarters, but then we waited all summer for

triple A to warm up for a second round and
all we got was three semi-energetic thrusts

on one day in October and then they came in
our eye socket, rolled over and fucking went
to sleep.

So now we&#39;re just killing time with acrimonious
arguments over who&#39;s sleeping on the wet patch

and paying for the Uber in the morning and
there&#39;s nothing else coming out this year
but ports and remakes.
You haven&#39;t reviewed CoD: WW2 yet, Yahtz.
Oh but I have, viewer.

I&#39;ve reviewed CoD: WW2 more times than I can
count.

Sometimes it&#39;s called Call of Duty and sometimes
it&#39;s called Battlefield and sometimes it&#39;s

called Medal of Honour but it is always nonetheless
the same: a lot of Nazis will die and we&#39;ll

all learn important lessons about duty and
brotherhood before we join the multiplayer

and listen to a bunch of grown men calling
each other faggots for stealing their kills

while the publisher tries to tacitly convince
us to blow our life&#39;s savings on premium VD
medicine.

Besides, going back to world war 2 is a shamelessly
retrograde move that I don&#39;t want to encourage
because next platform shoes might come back.

Triple-A these days is only triple-A in the
sense that the word &quot;Aggravating&quot; also has
three A&#39;s in it.

I think we should attempt trial separation
from triple-A until at least the new year.
So let&#39;s play some god damn indies.

Hand of Fate 2 is an action-packed high fantasy
game consisting entirely of one incredibly

long and boring coach ride during which we&#39;re
stuck sitting opposite a really ugly nun who

is going to insist on teaching you her favourite
card game no matter how many times you suggest
switching to the Travel Scrabble.

So what we have here is a hybrid of a deck-building
game and a D&amp;D session being run by someone
who&#39;s just a little bit too into it.

The premise being that we&#39;re using the game
to go over the events of our adventuring life

thus far that led us to only being able to
afford a seat in economy class.

This being the case, my adventurous life seems
to have consisted of an awful lot of repeating

the same adventure multiple times and swearing
at dice.

The actual gameplay of each campaign consists
of moving from encounter to encounter, except

beforehand you get to pick what random encounters
are included in the deck alongside the ones
required by the story.

Mostly the challenge is centred around juggling
probability and resource management, until

the need for combat suddenly arises, at which
point the game chucks all that numbers bullshit

in the bin and puts you out with some monsters
for a few minutes so you can twat each other
with sticks.

Kind of like live action role playing, I suppose,
except that you can die of something other
than embarrassment.

&quot;I can&#39;t help noticing that great big 2 hanging
off the title like a big coiled turd that

won&#39;t break off, Yahtz, do I need to have
played Hand of Fate 1?&quot;
Not really, imaginary questioner.

I&#39;d put Hand of Fate 2 alongside Left 4 Dead
2 in the category of sequels that kinda make

the original obsolete because it&#39;s basically
the same game but fleshed out and with more
bells and whistles.

Some of which did feel like gilding the lily
a tad.

Like character customisation options, whatever
helps you get immersed, sure, but in a game

where most of your actions are being merely
described in text, doesn&#39;t feel like our appearance

matters much unless the text contrives for
the action to frequently take place in a hairdresser&#39;s.

Also, as well as deciding random outcomes
with the success-failure three-card monte,

we&#39;ve now got dice rolls and a weird stop
the pendulum game.

I guess the pendulum is theoretically more
skill-based than random, but in practise,
it can get fucked.

The thing you&#39;re trying to point at is commonly
about the size of a bush baby&#39;s bollocks and

I swear there&#39;s a very slight controller delay
so trying to skillfully hit the target has

roughly the same success rate as putting the
controller in a bag of marbles and kicking
it across the room.

On the whole though, this shit is quite my
jam.

Disclaimer: do not use shit as jam, it will
make for a poor morning&#39;s breakfast.

But I&#39;ve got a fondness for this sort of FTL-style
procedural storytelling, and by strange coincidence

I also enjoy the counter-centric Batman Arkham-style
combat.

If you only like one of those things you might
not enjoy the way the other keeps interrupting

it, but for me, having a special button that
lets me take a break from all this fiddling

about with cards and numbers so I can beat
the snot out of the characters for two minutes

is a feature I could do with in virtually
any game.
It&#39;d certainly liven up Animal Crossing.

It might not be the most elegantly designed
combat in the world - I feel like it uses
too many buttons.

One for attack, one for other attack, one
for special attack, one for finisher attack,

one for block, one for evade and one for the
little boy who lives down the lane.

And more often than not the enemies clump
together and the action becomes a big confusing

rugby scrum where the counter prompts are
pretty much all you have to go on.
But no deals have been broken thus far.

What can be a bit galling is when you&#39;ve carefully
optimised your deck and spent an hour getting

lucky rolls and calculating yourself into
the perfect position only to lose it all on

the final boss fight because you failed to
dodge his dickslap finisher.

Or the other way around, maybe you&#39;re down
to five health but masterfully fought off

sixteen guys without taking a single hit,
only for the next random card to take fifteen

health off you because you tried to pick up
a coin and accidentally punched yourself in
the balls.

See, it&#39;s where the game switches between
its two distinct gameplay cores that there&#39;s
the occasional grinding of gears.

Personally I&#39;m not that interested in the
whole deck building concept, it&#39;s the sort

of thing I&#39;ve come to associate with odd-smelling
rooms above comic book shops into which large

numbers of Cheetos unwittingly wander and
are never seen again.

The whole process of building my encounter
deck before every campaign was a bit of a
chore.

Yes, there&#39;s a button to automatically fill
out the deck but I swiftly found I couldn&#39;t

trust it, it was always leaving out interesting
new cards and leaving in that fucking overpriced

pie shop and that one ring that reduces fire
damage when the main enemy that uses fire

is about as hard to dodge as a Republican
tax code.

I think the major issue I have with this otherwise
unique and absorbing game is one of momentum.

Some of the campaigns can go on for very long
and when I fail them right at the last hurdle

I&#39;d feel quite disheartened and unsure if
I could stand to start all over again.

What might help is, say, a quick restart button
I could press at this point to just shuffle

the decks and start again, bish bash bosh
and no bovvah.

What most certainly does not help is to dangle
the victory token in front of me for a minute

going &quot;Ooh look at this lovely shiny thing
you&#39;re not going to have now.

Better flamboyantly put it back in my pile
of things that aren&#39;t for losers before I

make all the cards fly around the room for
five minutes and kick you back to the deck

building screen so you can try to figure out
where you fucked this up.&quot;

A slave to the swishy wishy effects, this
game, nothing moves unless it can fly around
a bit first.

Yes, I understand some of this is probably
covering loading times, which is presumably

why we have to stare at a Winamp visualisation
from the early 2000s for a minute before every
combat, but it&#39;s a bit of a pace killer.
So that&#39;s Hand of Fate.

It&#39;s like finding your mum&#39;s vibrator as a
kid.

It&#39;s intriguing and you can have fun with
it but it&#39;s occasionally sticky in ways that
probably aren&#39;t worth thinking about.
